data.title: What Happened in November 1909
data.meta_description: What happened in November 1909. Browse historical events, famous birthdays and notable deaths from Nov 1909 or search by date, day or keyword.
data.text:
Historical Events

Susanna's Secret

Ermanno Wolf-Ferrari's opera "Il Segreto di Susanna" (Susanna's Secret) is first produced in Munich

Knights of St Peter Claver founded in Mobile, Alabama; Ladies Auxiliary formed in 1922

Construction of US navy base begins at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii

Nov 11 J M Synge's "Tinker's Wedding" premieres in London

Mackenzie King

Politician William Lyon Mackenzie King takes his seat in the House of Commons as Canda's first Minister of Labour

259 miners die in a fire at St Paul Mine at Cherry, Illinois

Nov 13 Ben Simpson of Hamilton Tigers kicks 9 singles in 14-4 win over the Argos at Rosedale Field in Toronto

Nov 13 Collier's magazine accuses U.S. Secretary of the Interior Richard Ballinger of questionable dealings in Alaskan coal fields

Dutch football club FC Eindhoven is founded in southern part of the city; Eredivisie 1954; KNVB Cup 1937

US invades Nicaragua, later overthrows President Zelaya

Kuyper Denies Corruption

Former Dutch premier Abraham Kuyper denies corruption

Jack Williams of Canadian football team Ottawa Rough Riders kicks 9 singles in a game

7.17" (18.2 cm) of rainfall, Rattlesnake Creek, Idaho (state record)

Nov 23 Wright Brothers form million dollar corporation to manufacture airplanes

Sigma Alpha Mu is founded in the City College of New York by 8 Jewish young men.

Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3

Sergei Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3, one of the genres most difficult, premieres at the New Theatre in New York City, with the composer as soloist and the New York Symphony Society conducted by Walter Damrosch

Australian Victory

International Lawn Tennis Challenge, Sydney, Australia: Norman Brookes & Anthony Wilding beat Americans Melville Long & Maurice McLoughlin 12-10, 9-7, 6-3; Australasia unassailable 3-0 lead; win 5-0

People's Budget

British House of Lords rejects David Lloyd George's 'People's Budget', which tried to shift tax burden to the wealthy. Leads to the Parliament Act; intent to stop unelected house overruling will of the elected house.

Famous Birthdays

Bruno Bjelinski [Weiss], Croatian composer, born in Trieste, Austria-Hungary (d. 1992)

James Reston, American journalist (New York Times), born in Clydebank, Dunbartonshire, Scotland (d. 1995)

Nov 3 Otto Bonsema, Dutch soccer striker (6 caps; Velocitas 1897, GVAV) and manager (SC Heerenveen, GVAV, BV Veendam), born in Groningen, Netherlands (d. 1994)

Bert Patenaude, American soccer forward (4 caps; scorer of first hat-trick in World Cup history, 1930), born in Fall River, Massachusetts (d. 1974)

Nov 4 Evelyn Johnson, American pilot (most flying hours - 57,685), born in Corbin, Kentucky (d. 2012)

Heinz Rottger, German composer, born in Herford, Germany (d. 1977)

Nov 6 Henk Bijvanck, Dutch composer, born in Kudus, Java (d. 1969)

Alberto Erede, Italian conductor, born in Genoa, Italy (d. 2001)

H. M. van Randwijk, Dutch author and founder (Vrij Netherland), born in Gorinchem, Netherlands (d. 1966)

Nov 9 Robert Douglas, English actor (Adv of Don Juan), born in Fenny Stratford, Buckinghamshire (d. 1999)

Paweł Jasienica, Polish historian, born in Ulyanovsk, Russia (d. 1970)

Robert Ryan, American actor (Billy Budd, The Dirty Dozen, The Longest Day), born in Chicago, Illinois (d. 1973)

Gunnar Bjornstrand, Swedish actor (Shame, Dreams), born in Stockholm, Sweden (d. 1986)

Nov 13 Paul de Vree, Flemish author (Between Doubt & Tears), born in Antwerp, Belgium (d. 1982)

Joseph McCarthy

American Senator (Rep - Wisconsin) who claimed communists infiltrated the US government, born in Grand Chute, Wisconsin

Gerald Savory, British actor playwright and TV producer (Heart of the Matter), born in London, England (d. 1996)

Johnny Mercer

American singer, Academy Award-winning lyricist ("Moon River"; "That Old Black Magic"; "And the Angels Sing": Come Rain Or Come Shine"), and record label executive (Capitol Records), born in Savannah, Georgia

Peter Drucker, Austrian-American management theorist, born in Kaasgraben, Vienna, Austria-Hungary (d. 2005)

Nov 19 Rose Isabel Williams, sister of Tennessee Williams, born in Gulfport, Mississippi (d. 1996)

Alan Bible, American lawyer and politician (Sen-D-Nev, 1954-74), born in Lovelock, Nevada (d. 1988)

Mikhail Mil, Russian aviation designer (d. 1970)

Nov 22 Moses Josiah Madiba, South African author and first African chancellor of the University of the North, born in Seshego, Pietersburg District (d. 1985)

Nov 22 Theodorus Zwartkruis, Dutch Bishop of Haarlem Netherlands (1966-83) (d. 1983)

Nigel Tranter, Scottish author and historian (River Realm; Robert the Bruce), born in Glasgow, Scotland (d. 2000)

Hans Melchior Brugk, German composer, born in Munich, Germany (d. 1999)

Nov 24 Hotze de Roos, Dutch youth book author (Chameleon) (d. 1991)

Hugh Davson, English physiologist (protein sandwich model), born in London (d. 1996)

Nov 25 Manny Martindale, West Indian cricket fast bowler (10 Tests, 37 wickets; Barbados), born in St Lucy, Barbados (d. 1972)

Eugene Ionesco

Romanian-French playwright (Rhinoceros, Bald Soprano), born in Slatina, Romania

Frances Dee, American actress (Of Human Bondage), born in Los Angeles, California (d. 2004)

Anatoly Maltsev, Russian mathematician (decidability of various algebraic groups), born in Moscow (d. 1967)

Nov 27 Donald John Urquhart, English librarian, born in Whitley Bay, England (d. 1994)

Nov 27 James Agee, American author (African Queen, Death in Family), born in Knoxville, Tennessee (d. 1955)

Aleksandar Ranković, Yugoslavic partisan and 1st Vice President of Yugoslavia (1963-66), born in Draževac, Serbia (d. 1983)

Nov 28 David Miller, American film director (Billy the Kid), born in Paterson, New Jersey (d. 1992)

Nov 28 Lotta Hitschmanova, Canadian humanitarian (founder of the Unitarian Service Committee of Canada), born in Prague, Bohemia (d. 1990) [1]

Rupert Davies, British Methodist scholar, born in London, England (d. 1994)

Robert Nighthawk [McCollum], American blues singer, electric slide guitarist, and harmonica player ("Annie Lee Blues"), born in Helena, Arkansas (d. 1967)

Famous Deaths

Wilhelm Ahlwardt, German orientalist, dies at 81

Charles Bordes, French composer, dies at 46

Nov 8 Eduard de Hartog, Dutch composer, dies at 80

George Essex Evans, Australian poet (b. 1863)

Nov 10 Ludvig Schytte, Danish pianist, composer, and educator, dies at 61 [1] [2]

Aeneas Mackay, Dutch Internal minister (ARP)/Colonization, dies at 70

Joshua Slocum, Canadian-American seaman and adventurer (first man to sail around the world alone), departs from Vineyard Haven, Massachusetts, sailing south for the winter, and is lost at sea, at 65

Francis Thome, French composer, dies at 59

Renee Vivien, British-born poet, wrote in French, dies at 32

Innokenti F Annenski, Russian poet and translator, dies at 53 [NS=Dec 13]
